reviewText:
The Descendant (Episode 1 & 2) is a casual, story rich, point and click adventure game that takes place on 2 different timelines.

Check out my Quick Review for Episode 1 here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e7ZlLg6apuM
UPDATED after playing episode 2
In The Descendant, you play as two different characters, one from the past timeline, and one from the present. So far, the game is a user-friendly point and click adventure, where you can only interact with objects in the proper sequence. The objectives are fairly straightforward. You can inspect various objects, but you can‚Äôt pick up anything that isn‚Äôt your current objective. The game has a few puzzles, but so far, nothing too complex. In between the point and click gameplay, there are choices in dialog selection, and other things that require you to react.

The story starts after a near-human extinction event, with what‚Äôs left of humanity trying to wake the survivors and rebuild. You don‚Äôt really know what exactly happened, but the mystery very intriguing.  When the episode ends, you probably won‚Äôt want to stop playing.

For the most part, your decisions in episode 1 seem to have the same or very similar outcome, but there was one set of actions that I did on my 3rd playthrough that resulted in a slightly different ending. It‚Äôs hard to say right now how much of an impact this will have on the later episodes, but for now, at least the game is showing potential that your decisions may have some weight to them. I still don't know why more save slots haven't been added though; I would like to play episode 2 again to try out different decisions, but I'm afraid it will make me start over.

Pros:nice graphics style, that is very similar to many of Telltale's games
really good narrative, and the sound effects and voice acting were done well
playing in the past timeline as well as the present timeline is a great way to understand the backstory (it's a nice change from just finding objects or notes for information)
really intriguing story, that will leave you wanting more
Cons:the controls cannot be changed and there is no controller support
a couple minor graphical issues: in some scenes the view seemed to jump/flicker to a different view, and there was also a door that after you blow it off the hinges, the door comes off as a different shape than where it came from
there was sometimes a delay after interacting with objects before you could click on the back button and start moving again UPDATED: Seems like this has been fixed.
characters sometimes walk in small circles when attempting to interact with some objects
game forces you to replay episode 1 before starting episode 2 (even though I already completed episode 1 three times)
STILL only 1 save slot, so it makes it a lot harder to replay to test out different choices
Both Episode 1 and Episode 2 each take 30-60 minutes to complete, depending on the player, and what decisions are made. You can replay the game to try making other decisions, but you can‚Äôt skip any of the cut scenes, so it is repetitive. Also, there was one part in episode 2 that I didn't agree with, and I would have liked to have had a choice to let me choose otherwise, but it doesn't change my review.

I don‚Äôt know exactly how long the next three episodes will be, but if they last about the same as the first episode, I can see waiting for a slight sale even though it‚Äôs priced similarly to some other Telltale adventure games. I am looking forward to finding out what happened, I hope the following episodes don‚Äôt take too long to release. You might want to wait for all the episodes to release because you will most likely be left wanting more story immediately.

Wow. This game honestly had me positively surprised. I went in with very low expectations, thinking it'd be a pretty boring game, but really, this was pretty entertaining! This game has a really captivating storyline that takes place in a very interesting - almost mysterious - environment which leaves you asking more questions than you can get the answer to (the cliffhangers!). I really love how the player's choice of different interactions paves the way for variety in the gameplay, adds a whole new dynamic and not just a dull gameplay where you sit and wait for something to happen. During certain missions you also have to solve puzzles which I think is a nice addition. You have to have an eye for details.

Apart from the relatively short first episode I wouldn't say I have a lot to complain about. Although it wouldn't hurt with a bit more to do considering the environment which is very rich with details. The developers should take that into account and probably let the player interact more with what is around them, but at the same time I can understand that it'd be annoying to press everything only to find out it doesn't provide something useful to the progression of the game.

All in all, I'd give this first episode a 7,5 / 10 in ratings. Definitely worth playing. After all though, thi is in fact the first point & click game I've played so I don't really have anything to compare it with, but I can say this won't be the last one for me. I'll definitely be following this series. Waiting patiently for the upcoming episodes!

reviewText:
Played Episode One.

The Descendant goes for the episodic Telltale mold, but fails to understand what made those games good. Instead of focusing on interesting characters, their personal relations and choices, we get cardboard cutout protagonists who don't have enough of a personality to even be called stereotypes.

It's the post-apocalypse again. And as established by post-apocalyptic rules, there's also a cryogenic vault. We get to follow two separate ventures into said vault; One maintenance crew shortly after and during the ICBM's hitting their targets, and one search & rescue crew hundreds of years later, wading through the derelict bunker.

I'm going to call these people the janitor woman of the past and the bicentennial rescue man, because that is pretty much the whole extent of what we get to know about these people during the first episode. Both of them are accompanied by an authoritarian sidekick figure who they can choose to either snub or obey in the game's few dialogue choices. Otherwise, the reason for their existence seems to be to feed us stuff to do.

Unfortunately, the stuff they're providing is very, very formulaic. Turn a valve. Flip a switch. Connect some wires -- Yes, I realize a janitor's regular day probably isn't that flashy in real life either, but come on! There's not an ounce of creativity at display here. The only thing missing is a hidden object scene.

I could maybe overlook the mundane puzzles if the gameplay was closer to Telltale's standards, but sadly that isn't the case. The camera angles have a tendency to mess up navigation since the viewpoint is usually switched when the character is already way too close to the screen border. However, a much bigger problem is the game's insistence on administering the clickable hotspots with a pipette.

Even if you can deduce a solution in advance, you usually have to try and fail or simply do the wrong thing first for the correct item to gain clickability. Did I mention that you also have to be reasonably close to a thing for it to show its icon in the first place? Well, you do.

I don't know. I'm all for new contenders entering the episodic adventure game space, but this here is not cutting it at all. With last years' Life is Strange, the bar originally set by Telltale has been raised; You cannot lower the standard well below the median and expect people to get hooked. During the final minutes of the first episode there's some very minor story intrigue, but nothing that'd compel me to buy the rest of the season. Nice facial animations, though.

reviewText:
Posted at Gizorama	[www.gizorama.com]

Telltale Games certainly made a splash when they released The Walking Dead: The Game. It seemed to be the best way to bring the point-and-click adventure genre to modern gaming. It allowed the developers to tell an emotional story that still gave the player a feeling of agency. It‚Äôs surprising how rarely that formula has been copied, with Life is Strange being the closest comparison.

The Descendant is now the closest thing to a straight copy-paste of the formula Telltale has mastered, but it‚Äôs boring characters, boring plot, boring‚Ä¶ everything make it a chore to get through it‚Äôs first episode.

The premise is simple enough. Global Warming caused wars between the world‚Äôs superpowers, ending in nuclear war. Sanctuaries known as Arks were built to house some of the world‚Äôs elite in cryosleep until‚Ä¶ well that‚Äôs unclear. These Arks are maintained by engineers known as Janitors, who are automatically awoken at key times to work on things like water heaters.

The Descendant‚Äôs first episode is split between three time periods, following two characters. In the past, Mia is the ‚Äúnew guy‚Äù on Ark-01, who works alongside one of the most poorly voice-acted characters I‚Äôve ever come across. There‚Äôs a weird moment where it feels like the game is interested in building some level of distrust between the characters. ‚ÄúWho are you?‚Äù asks Mia‚Äôs partner, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not the guy I expected.‚Äù Oddly, this tension between the characters is never suggested again.

In the future (‚ÄúCenturies later...‚Äù), you‚Äôll take control of Donnie, a one-time Janitor who is now partnered with a cranky, old Senator, tasked with investigating what happened at Ark-01. The Descendant jumps around periodically between Donnie and Mia, unravelling more of the mystery as the game goes on.

The basic premise of learning what occurred on Ark-01 is admittedly intriguing. Even though we‚Äôve seen this idea done to death (waking up years after the Apocalypse), The Descendant‚Äôs idea of turning it into a mystery is something that I haven‚Äôt seen done a million times. It‚Äôs unfortunate that the game is so bad at communicating exactly what the mystery is. Upon Donnie‚Äôs arrival, we don‚Äôt know anything that‚Äôs happened at Ark-01, so immediately, tension drops. Donnie makes a suggestion that the senator should stay behind (and you‚Äôre given 4 options of reasons why he should stay behind) because presumably there‚Äôs danger afoot. It‚Äôs unclear why Donnie feels this way. Is the world inhabited by mutants now? Was there signs of distress? Couldn‚Äôt the Ark have simply had a mechanical failure and everyone died in cryosleep?

There‚Äôs no reason to feel tension other than the fact that the developers lay on the thriller movie music. Even in the moments that feel like they should be tense, they aren‚Äôt because the controls don‚Äôt allow you to move your characters quickly. With the exception of one scene, the characters crawl along at an alarmingly slow pace considering meltdown seems to be occurring. Then these moments feature puzzles that require you to find a thing to make another thing work, so that you can get another thing to work. There‚Äôs no urgency and thus no tension. Then the episode - which took me all of 40 minutes to complete - ends with what I can only assume was intended to be an intense cliffhanger, but because I‚Äôd been so bored until that point, I couldn‚Äôt find it in me to care at all.

Everything about The Descendant‚Äôs first episode feels like a really boring SyFy original series, while Telltale‚Äôs games, while not perfect, tend to feel more like an AMC or HBO production in comparison. The Descendant‚Äôs low budget shows at every seam. The voice acting is bad to terrible, the writing is unsure of itself and never knows where to go, and the gamiest aspects are okay at best. The puzzles are simplistic, and the camera lingers in places that force your character to constantly walk into walls or get stuck in awkward positions.

The Descendant's first episode is a mess from beginning to end. It's near-interesting plot is brought down by bad execution (bad voice acting, bad pacing, bad animation). Thankfully it's only a briefly painful experience at 40 minutes.

1.5/5
